Protein shakes?

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎09-22-2010 03:15 AM

I am still experimenting with my food before I start to work out. When it comes to your pre-workout meal, what do you eat? I usually do wheat toast, or an energy bar with around 30g. I carry a container of juice with me so that when I need to have more carbs to extend my workout I have them right there.

My question is, for those who weight lift regularly with the intention of building and toning muscle, what part does protein play in your workout? I may have forgotten my diabetic educator lessons but doesn't protein help prolong the effect of the carbs you ingested, because like glucose protein is a viable source of ATP, which is what this all comes down to. The point being that with more than one source of ATP glucose is not used up as quickly. What about a protein shake that is equal parts carbs, protein and fat (which also is a source of ATP, though not one we like)? Do you find that increased amounts of protein in your pre-workout prolong your workout?

I am experimenting. Any input helps.
Report Inappropriate Content

Protein shakes?

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post

  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎09-22-2010 06:40 PM

I'm not qualified to answer a question for a Type 1, but I do weight training along with cardio. My usual time to go to the gym is after work. I find that a bit of protein along with a carb works best. Not alot of food tho. I do best on the 0 fat Greek Yoghurt. Protein and carb. One container is about 90 calories and 11 g of carb. ( I don't remember what the protein is) Protein shakes are good, possibly whey protein mixed with a bit of carb, but you have to figure out the amount of carb for you. I know that if I don't have a small snack and I do a pretty good workout, I'll loose steam. Especially if a low carb light lunch at 12:30. I get to the gym about 4:45PM.
I do know that with a better supply of fuel, I sustain my strength better. I played singles tennis last night for 1 1/2 hours before dinner. I had a very small glass of milk and a few bites of a peach, really not much food, but I won the set....so I think that a combination of protein and carb is the best.
Sorry if I didn't answer your question exactly. Lin
Clean eating low carb diet and exercise, cardio/weight training plus Tennis, Body Combat and Zumba 6 days a week. 500mg Metformin;2X; A1C 6.8 of 3/1/2014

‎09-22-2010 11:17 PM

Thanks for the advice Lin. I have heard lots of good things about whey protein and the consensus from my avid exercise friends is that I should do a mixture of whey and casein protein for the quick boost and then the long release. As for carbs, I have that pretty much figured out, but I will still experiment.

‎09-24-2010 03:51 AM

It is a protein that supposedly has a longer release time, so the whey is fast acting while weight lifting and the casein isn't absorbed as quickly so after you weight lift it is there to keep on repairing muscles.

I think. Or so I've heard.
